skill.name: deepchem
skill.description: Molecular ML with diverse featurizers and pre-built datasets. Use for property prediction (ADMET, toxicity) with traditional ML or GNNs when you want extensive featurization options and MoleculeNet benchmarks. Best for quick experiments with pre-trained models, diverse molecular representations. For graph-first PyTorch workflows use torchdrug; for benchmark datasets use pytdc.
skill.summary: Molecular ML with diverse featurizers and pre-built datasets. Use for property prediction (ADMET, to...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate scientific computing skill for molecular machine learning. All static analysis findings are false positives resulting from pattern matching without context understanding. The skill provides safe molecular property prediction capabilities using the DeepChem library.

content.user_title: Predict molecular properties with DeepChem ML
content.value_statement: DeepChem enables accurate molecular property prediction for drug discovery and materials science. Access 30+ benchmark datasets, graph neural networks, and pretrained models to accelerate cheminformatics research.
actual_capabilities: Load and process molecular data (SMILES, SDF, FASTA)
Predict ADMET properties, toxicity, and solubility
Train graph neural networks (GCN, GAT, AttentiveFP)
Apply transfer learning with ChemBERTa and GROVER
limitations: Requires chemistry domain knowledge for best results
Large datasets needed for graph neural networks (>10K)
PyTorch installation required for GNN models
Scaffold splitting essential to prevent data leakage

use_cases.title: Predict drug solubility and toxicity
use_cases.description: Evaluate ADMET properties early in drug discovery to prioritize promising compounds and avoid costly failures.

use_cases.title: Benchmark new molecular ML models
use_cases.description: Compare model performance on standardized MoleculeNet datasets with consistent train/test splits.

use_cases.title: Discover novel materials properties
use_cases.description: Predict crystal properties like bandgap and formation energy using graph-based representations.

prompt_templates.title: Quick solubility prediction
prompt_templates.prompt: Use DeepChem to predict aqueous solubility for these SMILES: CCO, c1ccccc1, CN1C=NC2=C1C(=O)N(C(=O)N2C)C. Load the Delaney dataset, train a Random Forest model with ECFP fingerprints, and report predictions with confidence intervals.

prompt_templates.title: Train GNN on custom data
prompt_templates.scenario: Build graph neural network for molecular properties
prompt_templates.prompt: Train a Graph Convolutional Network using my molecules.csv file. Use scaffold splitting, MolGraphConvFeaturizer, and predict the 'activity' column. Evaluate with ROC-AUC and compare to Random Forest baseline.

prompt_templates.title: Transfer learning setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Fine-tune pretrained model on small dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply transfer learning with ChemBERTa to classify BBBP permeability. Use 2e-5 learning rate, 10 epochs, and scaffold splitting. Compare performance to training from scratch.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-task learning
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a multi-task model to predict solubility, toxicity, and LogP together. Use the Tox21 dataset, implement early stopping, and analyze task correlation effects on performance.

output_examples.input: Predict solubility for aspirin and caffeine using DeepChem
output: Trained Random Forest with ECFP fingerprints (RÂ² = 0.89)
Both compounds have moderate solubility suitable for oral drugs

best_practices: Always use ScaffoldSplitter for molecular datasets to prevent data leakage from similar structures
Start with CircularFingerprint and Random Forest for quick baselines before trying complex models
Normalize both features and targets using NormalizationTransformer for better convergence
anti_patterns: Using RandomSplitter for drug discovery tasks leads to overly optimistic performance estimates
Training GNNs on small datasets (<1000 samples) often underperforms compared to fingerprints
Forgetting to apply the same transformers to test data that were used for training

faq.question: Which model should I use for small datasets?
faq.answer: Use Random Forest with CircularFingerprint for datasets under 1000 molecules. It's fast, robust, and requires minimal tuning.

faq.question: When should I use graph neural networks?
faq.answer: GNNs excel with large datasets (>10K molecules) and capture complex molecular relationships. Start with GCN or AttentiveFP.

faq.question: How do I prevent data leakage in molecular ML?
faq.answer: Always use ScaffoldSplitter which ensures structurally similar molecules don't appear in both training and test sets.

faq.question: What's the best featurizer for traditional ML?
faq.answer: CircularFingerprint (ECFP) works well with Random Forest and XGBoost, capturing local molecular environments effectively.

faq.question: Can I use pretrained models?
faq.answer: Yes, DeepChem supports ChemBERTa, GROVER, and MolFormer for transfer learning, especially useful for small datasets.

faq.question: How do I handle imbalanced classification?
faq.answer: Use BalancingTransformer to rebalance training data, or evaluate with balanced_accuracy_score instead of accuracy.
